trans-unit.source: Represents a splitter control that enables the user to resize docked controls.
<xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter"></xref> has been replaced by <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer"></xref> and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control enables the user to resize controls that are docked to the edges of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control at run time.

When the user passes the mouse pointer over the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control, the cursor changes to indicate that the controls docked to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control can be resized.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control enables the user to resize the docked control that is immediately before it in the docking order.

Therefore, to enable the user to resize a docked control, dock the control you want the user to be able to resize to an edge of a container, and then dock a splitter to the same side of that container.

For example, to create a window similar to Windows Explorer, add a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> control to a form and set its <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Dock%2A> property to `DockStyle.Left`.
Add a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control to the form and set its <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Dock%2A> property to `DockStyle.Left` as well.

To complete the form layout, add a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control and set its <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Dock%2A> property to `DockStyle.Fill` to have the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> occupy the remaining space on the form.

At run time, the user can then resize the width of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> control (as well as the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control) by moving the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control.

To ensure that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control does not resize controls docked to a size that is too small to be useful to the user, you use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize%2A> properties.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize%2A> properties determine the minimum size that controls docked to the left and right (or top and bottom if a horizontal <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control) can be sized to.

If the other controls on your form that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to display a specific style of border, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.BorderStyle%2A> property to match the border style of the controls that are docked to it.
You might want to set a maximum size limit on controls that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving> events enable you to determine when the user is resizing a docked control.

You can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitPosition%2A> property in an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving> events to determine the size of the control that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to and set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitPosition%2A> property to a different value to limit the docked control's width to a specified maximum width (or height if a horizontally aligned <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control).
Resizing a control using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control can only be done using the mouse.
It is not possible to access the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control using the keyboard.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter"></xref> class.
<xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter"></xref> has been replaced by <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer"></xref>, and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.
By default, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra%2A> properties are set to 25.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Dock%2A> property is set to `DockStyle.Left` by default.
This property is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
`true` if enabled; otherwise, `false`.
This property is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AnchorStyles"></xref> values.
This property is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
The background image displayed in the control.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImageLayout"></xref> values.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
Gets or sets the style of border for the control.

<xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.BorderStyle"></xref> has been replaced by <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.BorderStyle"></xref> and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.

This property is typically used when the controls the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to are displayed with a specific border style and you want the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control to match their display style.

For example, if you have a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control will be docked to that you want to display without any borders, you can set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.BorderStyle%2A> property to `BorderStyle.None`.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.BorderStyle"></xref> values.
The default is `BorderStyle.None`.
The value of the property is not one of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.BorderStyle"></xref> values.
Returns the parameters needed to create the handle.
Inheriting classes can override this property to provide extra functionality.
Be sure, however, that these classes call `base.getCreateParams()` first to get the structure containing the basic information.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.CreateParams"></xref> that contains the required creation parameters when the handle to the control is created.
Gets or sets the default cursor for the control.
An object of type <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> representing the current default cursor.
Gets the default Input Method Editor (IME) mode supported by this control.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImeMode"></xref> values.
Gets the default size of the control.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Size"></xref> that represents the default size of the control.

Gets or sets which <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter"></xref> borders are docked to its parent control and determines how a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter"></xref> is resized with its parent.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.Dock%2A> property to define how a control is automatically resized as its parent control is resized.

You can only set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.Dock%2A> property to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Top>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Bottom>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Left>, or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Right>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control enables the user to resize the docked control that is immediately before it in the docking order.
Therefore, to enable the user to resize a docked control, dock the control to an edge of a container, and then dock a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control to the same side of that container.
For more information, see the example in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> class.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle"></xref> values.
The default is <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Left"></xref>.
<xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.Dock"></xref> is not set to one of the valid <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle"></xref> values.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
The font of the text displayed by the control.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
The foreground color of the control.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImeMode"></xref> values.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
Gets or sets the minimum distance that must remain between the splitter control and the edge of the opposite side of the container (or the closest control docked to that side).

<xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra"></xref> has been replaced by similar properties in <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer"></xref> and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.

For a horizontal <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control (a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control docked to the top or bottom of a container), the minimum height of the area of the container reserved for undocked controls is this value minus the height of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control.

For a vertical <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control (a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control docked to the left or right of a container), the minimum width of the area of the container reserved for undocked controls is this value minus the width of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control.
The user cannot move the splitter past the limit specified by this property.
If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra%2A> property is set to a negative value, the property value is reset to 0.

The minimum distance, in pixels, between the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter"></xref> control and the edge of the opposite side of the container (or the closest control docked to that side).
The default is 25.
Gets or sets the minimum distance that must remain between the splitter control and the container edge that the control is docked to.

<xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize"></xref> has been replaced by <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.Panel1MinSize"></xref> and <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.Panel2MinSize"></xref> and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.

For a horizontal <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control (a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control docked to the top or bottom of a container), this value is the minimum height of the resizable control.

For a vertical <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control (a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control docked to the left or right of a container), this value is the minimum width of the resizable control.
The user cannot move the splitter past the limit specified by this property.
If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize%2A> property is set to a negative value, the property value is reset to 0.
The minimum distance, in pixels, between the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter"></xref> control and the container edge that the control is docked to.
The default is 25.
This method is not relevant to this class.
This method is not relevant to this class.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.KeyEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.MouseDown"></xref> event.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.OnMouseDown%2A> method begins dragging the `Splitter` control to resize the docked control that is immediately before `Splitter` in the docking order.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.MouseMove"></xref> event.

If the user holds down left mouse button and moves the mouse, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.OnMouseMove%2A> method moves the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control to resize the docked control that is immediately before <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> in the docking order.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.MouseUp"></xref> event.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.OnMouseUp%2A> method resizes the docked control that is immediately before Splitter in the docking order.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved"></xref> event.

<xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.OnSplitterMoved(System.Windows.Forms.SplitterEventArgs)"></xref> has been replaced by <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.OnSplitterMoved(System.Windows.Forms.SplitterEventArgs)"></xref> and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.OnSplitterMoved%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitterEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving"></xref> event.

<xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.OnSplitterMoving(System.Windows.Forms.SplitterEventArgs)"></xref> has been replaced by <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.OnSplitterMoving(System.Windows.Forms.SplitterCancelEventArgs)"></xref> and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.OnSplitterMoving%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitterEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Performs the work of setting the specified bounds of this control.
The new <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Left"></xref> property value of the control.
The new <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Top"></xref> property value of the control.
The new <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Width"></xref> property value of the control.
The new <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Height"></xref> property value of the control.
A bitwise combination of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.BoundsSpecified"></xref> values.
Gets or sets the distance between the splitter control and the container edge that the control is docked to.

<xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitPosition"></xref> has been replaced by <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.Panel1MinSize"></xref> and <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.Panel2MinSize"></xref> and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.

For a horizontal <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control (a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control docked to the top or bottom of a container), this value is the height of the resizable control.

For a vertical <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control (a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control docked to the left or right of a container), this value is the width of the resizable control.

You can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitPosition%2A> property in an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving> events to determine the size of the control that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to and limit its width to a specified maximum width (or height if a horizontally docked <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control).
The distance, in pixels, between the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter"></xref> control and the container edge that the control is docked to.
If the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter"></xref> control is not bound to a control, the value is -1.
Occurs when the splitter control is moved.

<xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved"></xref> has been replaced by <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.SplitterMoved"></xref> and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.
You can create an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> event to perform resize validation in your application.

For example, if a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to the edges of a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> control and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control, you can write code in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> event to determine if the minimum and/or maximum size for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> controls has been exceeded and resize the controls to their minimum or maximum size.
For more information about handling events, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
Occurs when the splitter control is in the process of moving.

<xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving"></xref> has been replaced by <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.SplitterMoving"></xref> and is provided only for compatibility with previous versions.
You can create an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving> event to perform resize validation in your application.

For example, if a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control is docked to the edges of a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> control and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control, you can write code in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> event to determine if the minimum and/or maximum size for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TreeView> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> controls has been exceeded and restrict the resizing of the controls to their minimum or maximum size.
For more information about handling events, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
This property is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
`true` if enabled; otherwise, `false`.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
A string.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
Returns a string that represents the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter"></xref> control.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.ToString%2A> method returns a string that includes the type and the values for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinSize%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.MinExtra%2A> properties.
A string that represents the current <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Splitter"></xref>.
